awd_titl_txt: Developing Teachers' Capacity to Promote Argumentation in Secondary Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will produce insights into the challenges teachers face in modifying their teaching in the substantial and complex ways demanded by the Next Generation Science Standards. This project will develop and study a program of professional development to help middle and high school science teachers support their students to learn to argue scientifically. The program includes strategies for organizing science activities to create contexts where students have something to argue about and teaching practices that promote sustained, productive argumentation among students. Results will document what aspects of these new practices teachers find easier and more difficult to implement, and how challenges are influenced by the urban schooling contexts in which project teachers work. The project will also further our understanding of how site-based professional development can be structured to support teacher learning and improvement.

The project is a longitudinal study of a cohort of 30 secondary science teachers from an urban school district in California. The professional development (PD) program will be organized around intensive summer institutes followed by 2 school-based lesson study cycles each year, facilitated by trained coaches. The PD work will be carried out over three years. All PD sessions will be recorded for interaction analysis to identify variations in coaching and teacher participation and the influences of such variation on teacher learning. Repeated measures of teachers' conceptions of argumentation will be given over 3 years as a measure of teacher learning. An observation protocol will be developed and used to measure teacher talk and its change over time. A sub-sample of teachers' classrooms will be video recorded to produce a longitudinal record for interaction analyses to link teacher talk to patterns of student argumentation. The third year of the project will add measures of student learning and link them to variations in teacher practice. The final year of the project will produce retrospective analyses that link pathways in teacher learning to features of the PD program and teachers' participation. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

por.por_cntn:
Teaching science such that young people develop both deep conceptual understanding of scientific ideas and about how science works demands that students have regular and sustained opportunities to argue about both the ideas they are working to understand and the science practices they are using to understand them. Such teaching is exceedingly rare in secondary schools and most teachers have little or no experience with it. This project pursued 4 goals to help teachers learn to promote and support productive scientific arguments in their classrooms: 1) develop an instructional model for argumentation; 2) develop a professional development model to support teachers to learn that instructional model; 3) develop evidence of changes in teaching practice for teachers who take such professional development; and 4) link changes in teaching to changes in students’ opportunities to argue scientifically. The project followed a design-based research approach to create, study, and refine professional development with these aims. A group of 25 secondary science teachers in an urban school district, serving an economically diverse, primarily Latino community, participated in sustained professional development (PD) for 3 consecutive years (with roughly 50 contact hours per year). PD sessions were videorecorded to trace teachers’ conversations with project staff and each other over time. Selected classroom lessons were observed or videorecorded to capture teachers’ instructional practice. In the final year, student work artifacts were collected to examine opportunities to learn.

 

The project extended an instructional model for argumentation initiated in a prior award (DRL #0733233). The model includes mapping opportunities for argument in the science and engineering practices described in the Next Generation Science Standards, strategies for orchestrating and managing productive arguments, and rationales for the value of arguments for students’ science learning. While the content of specific arguments and criteria for evaluating the quality of arguments will vary between subjects and grade levels, the instructional model can be applied generally.

 

The project developed a professional development model derived from the challenges teachers encountered in learning to open up space for student argumentation and the project team’s responses to those challenges. The model includes four pillars. The first is “planning for coherence”: planning instructional units in ways that promote coherence for students. The second is “framing clear aims” for all instructional activities, so that students understand what they are trying to do and why it is meaningful. The third is “establish a culture of science talk”: creating classroom norms that encourage students to express and compare ideas about both the phenomena they are working to understand and about how to do that work. The final pillar is “practicing science to develop disciplinary ideas” as described in the Next Generation Science Framework. The order of these pillars indicates our experience of the ease with which teachers comprehended and could enact them. Teachers in the project found it easier to interrogate and improve the coherence of their lessons and to be more intentional about how they framed instructional tasks, but found it harder to put their students in situations where they could genuinely argue about how to do things or engage in legitimate versions of science practice.

 

The project contributed important knowledge to science teacher education in describing these challenges and pointing toward strategies for helping teachers learn these new practices. The project also developed a new technique for analyzing classroom interaction that characterizes differences in activity framing (how teachers communicate the purpose of an activity) in relation to student agency and the versions of science practice available to students (rote school activities v. genuine opportunities to experiment, analyze data, etc.). This technique allows instructional practice to be documented in a way that supports comparisons between teachers and over time, while linking rating judgments directly to episodes of interaction that can be analyzed closely as needed.

 

The project trained 5 graduate students, 6 undergraduates, and 1 postdoctoral scholar. It supported the development and refinement of a more robust and sustainable model of professional development for our institutional PD provider, as well as increasing the capacity for continued teacher learning in the partner school district. To date, the project has produced approximately 20 presentations at research and practitioner conferences, 9 refereed publications, and 3 book chapters.
